<QuestionBlock type="reading-content">
<Question level={1}>How is Russell using the term "idleness"?</Question>
<Question type="reading-discussion" level={2}>Do you think he means "no activity" or does he have in mind certain kinds of activities that distinct from "non-idle activities"?</Question>
<Question type="reading-discussion" level={2}>Can you think of an example of the kinds of "idle activities" he has in mind?</Question>
<Question type="reading-discussion" level={2}>Why does he see value in these kinds of activities?</Question>
</QuestionBlock>

<QuestionBlock type="reading-content">
<Question level={1}>What is Russell's primary proposal? What does he think is new about the modern era that makes this proposal possible?</Question>
</QuestionBlock>

<QuestionBlock type="reading-content">
<Question level={1}>Can you identify the distinct objections to this proposal that he lists?</Question>
<Question type="reading-discussion" level={2}>Which objection struck you as the most compelling and why? (Be ready to share.)</Question>
<Question level={1}>How does he answer that objection?</Question>
<Question type="reading-discussion" level={2}>Do you find his response convincing? Why or why not?</Question>
</QuestionBlock>

<QuestionBlock type="reading-discussion">
<Question level={1}>
Imagine an employer offers you the following proposal: You can either work a 20-hour work week and get paid $50,000 a year or you can work a 60-hour work week for $80,000. Identify which choice you think you would make and why? 
</Question>
<Question level={2}>Does Russell’s argument motivate you to choose the 20-hour work week? Why or why not?</Question>
<Question level={2}>Be attentive to the details of how you are making this choice. What ultimate activities or goals do you have in view? What other factors influence your decision besides these target activities or goals?</Question>
</QuestionBlock>

posts.content: What do you think is Meno's basic difficulty at the opening of this dialogue? Why is he not able to define virtue? {/* (70a-80d) */} How does this difficulty illustrate the difference between a definition and instances of that definition (12a-18a)? {/* (80d-e) */} As Socrates turns to look for his own definition of virtue, what objection does he face (18b-top) ? How does he attempt to answer that objection? {/* (81b-82a) */} (Hint: what does he mean by recollection?) (18b-bttm - 19a-top) {/* (82b and following) */} How does Socrates try to illustrate his theory of recollection through his interaction with the slave boy (19a-mid and following)? To help you understand this complicated exchange note that Plato is trying to get the slave boy to recognize the following geometrical truth: A square (BEHD) whose area is twice that of a given square (ABCD) is the square (BEHD) formed using the diagonal of the square (ABCD) as one of its four sides. {/* */} During the exchange, does Socrates ever teach the boy or give the boy new information? Or does the boy discover everything for himself? Can you think of other examples of this kind of learning? Can you think of an example where you must have already known "something", but if someone had asked you before, you would have probably said you didn't know it? {/* 97b */} What is the difference between knowledge and opinion that begins to be discussed at 29a-top? How does Socrates illustrate this difference with his obscure reference to the statues of Daedalus and runaway slaves? {/* 98a */} * The passage at 29b-top is a key passage in this text, so I want to offer one alternative translation from G.M.A. Grube: * "To acquire an untied work of Daedalus is not worth much, like acquiring a runaway slave, for it does not remain, but it is worth much if *tied down*, for his works are very beautiful. What am I thinking of when I say this? True opinions. For true opinions, as long as they remain, are a fine thing and all they do is good, but they are not willing to remain long, and they escape from a man's mind, **so that they are not worth much until one ties them down by [giving] an account of the reason why.**" At 29b-top or in the above passage, how does Socrates suggest that one "fasten" or "tie down" an opinion so that it becomes knowledge? If holding a "true opinion/belief" means that we believe what is true (that is, we have an accurate belief about the world), why do we need something called "knowledge"? In Plato's terms, why is better to have a true opinion that has been "tied down"? Can you think of some concrete situations where "true opinion" might not be sufficient, perhaps a situation where having "true opinion" but not knowledge is dangerous or simply unsatisfying?

posts.content: Make sure to complete the "Categorical Proposition Worksheet" and turn it in via moodle before Friday's class.

No reading questions for today. 

Please, just work through 
the assigned reading on Categorical Syllogisms 
and come to class ready to go over the material.

# Some Background

We're going to turn a text called *Meditations on First Philosophy* by Rene Descartes. 

This text was first written in 1641 (so many years after Plato and Aristotle) and it is our first introduction to a modern philosopher. 

The reason we're going to focus on this text (apart from it being a classic, and therefore *foundational* text) is that it is going to ask us to look  closely at the process of induction. 

Specifically, it is going to pose questions about the level of certainty that can be generated from the kind of inductive reasoning described by Aristotle (e.g. starting from sense observations, then moving to memory, then experience, and finally developing a general principle or definition).

Descartes is going to raise some serious doubts about whether certainty can be achieved in this way. This doubt and concern will be the focus of *Meditation* 1.

But Descartes is not only critic. He does not just want to cast doubt; he wants to also find a **new foundation** for certainty. So we will want to observe his method in *Meditations* 2 and 3 for how he thinks he can find certainty after doubting everything he previously held to be true. 

We will also want to observe the pros and cons of this method. What kinds of things might it give us certainty about? Are there limitations to how far this certainty extends?

With that in mind, below are some guided reading questions to help us navigate *Meditation* 1.

<QuestionBlock type="reading-content">
  <Question level={1}>Focus first on paragraph 1.</Question>
  <Question level={2}>What is problem does Descartes thinks he is facing?</Question>
  <Question level={2}>What is he searching for that he thinks will help him resolve this problem?</Question>
</QuestionBlock>

<QuestionBlock type="reading-content">
  <Question level={1}>Focus now on paragraph 2.</Question>
  <Question level={2}>Does Descartes think he needs to prove every one of his beliefs false? Why or why not?</Question>
  <Question level={2}>In order to remove all beliefs that could possible be wrong, what does he think it is sufficient to do?</Question>
</QuestionBlock>

<QuestionBlock type="reading-content">
  <Question level={1}>What kind of principle (or source of knowledge) does he focus on in paragraph 4 and 5</Question>
  <Question level={2}>Why does he think there is reason to doubt this principle?</Question>
  <Question level={2}>Does he given an argument for this?</Question>
  <Question level={3}>Can you find something that looks like a conclusion here?</Question>
  <Question level={3}>Can you identify any premises (or supporting reasons) for this conclusion?</Question>
  <Question level={3}>Try diagramming how the different premises (or supporting reasons) work together to lead to the conclusion.</Question>
</QuestionBlock>

<QuestionBlock type="reading-content">
  <Question level={1}>What new kind of principle of certainty does he begin to focus on in paragraphs 6, 7, and 8?</Question>
  <Question level={2}>At first, why do these kinds of beliefs seem to be more certain?</Question>
  <Question level={2}>In paragraph 9 what reason(s) does he offer to think that even these kinds of beliefs can be doubted?</Question>
  <Question level={2}>Again, does he given an argument for this?</Question>
  <Question level={3}>Can you find something that looks like a conclusion here?</Question>
  <Question level={3}>Can you identify any premises (or supporting reasons) for this conclusion?</Question>
  <Question level={3}>Try diagramming how the different premises (or supporting reasons) work together to lead to the conclusion.</Question>
</QuestionBlock>

<QuestionBlock type="reading-content">
  <Question level={1}>Related to his goal stated in paragraph 1, what conclusion (or mental state) has he reached in paragraph 10-12?</Question>
  <Question level={2}>Was he able to find the goal he was searching for or not?</Question>
</QuestionBlock>

## Meditation 2 

<QuestionBlock type="reading-content">
  <Question level={1}>How does Descartes summarize his current problem and goal in paragraph 1?</Question>
  <Question level={2}>In what way is he like Archimedes?</Question>
</QuestionBlock>

<QuestionBlock type="reading-content">
  <Question level={1}>How does Paragraph 2 review the results achieved in Meditation 1?</Question>
</QuestionBlock>

<QuestionBlock type="reading-content">
  <Question level={1}>Has Descartes made a break through in paragraph 3? Has he found something indubitable?</Question>
  <Question level={2} type="reading-discussion">Spend sometime reflecting here.</Question>
  <Question level={2} type="reading-discussion">What has he found?</Question>
  <Question level={2} type="reading-discussion">Why does he think this belief must be certain? What gives him confidence that it must exist and cannot be doubted</Question>
</QuestionBlock>

In paragraph 4, 5, and following, Descartes begins to examine what can be said about this "existent thing".

<QuestionBlock type="reading-content">
  <Question level={1}>What were some of the typical beliefs that Descartes used to attribute to this existent thing? Why is he no longer comfortable holding these beliefs? (Para 5)</Question>
  <Question level={1}>In para 6, what is the only "indubitable" characteristic he feels comfortable contributing to this existent thing? Why?</Question>
  <Question level={2} type="reading-discussion">Reflect a little yourself: does this feel like an "indubitable" claim or do you still have doubts?</Question>
  <Question level={2} type="reading-discussion">Are there any other attributes about yourself that you think are indubitable? Why or why not?</Question>
  <Question level={1}>How does his reasoning in para 6, escape the very difficult problem of an "Evil/Malicious/Deceiving God"? What must be certain even if he is being deceived by such a God?</Question>

</QuestionBlock>

In paragraph 8 and following, the inquiry goes deeper. Having established that is a thinking thing, Descartes examines what it means to be a thinking thing.

<QuestionBlock type="reading-content">
  <Question level={1}>What does he come up with here in para 8? What does it mean to be a "thinking thing"? Can you make a list of attributes?</Question>
  <Question level={2} type="reading-discussion">Spend some time evaluating his conclusion.</Question>
  <Question level={3} type="reading-discussion">Does this seem like an accurate and "indubitable" description of a thinking thing?</Question>
  <Question level={3} type="reading-discussion">Is there more that you could "indubitably" add to this description? What would it be?</Question>
</QuestionBlock>

Read paragraph 11-16 carefully. Paragraphs 11-16 include Descartes' extremely famous example of the "wax seal".

<QuestionBlock type="reading-content">
  <Question level={1}>What is Descartes trying to prove with this example?</Question>
  <Question level={1}>How is this intended to overturn conventional thinking about the certainty of what we sensibly perceive?</Question>
  <Question level={1}>In the closing paragraph (para 16), how does his examination of "perception" of the wax give him confidence that his "mental perception" of himself as a thinking thing cannot be doubted?</Question>
</QuestionBlock>

## Meditation 3 

Meditation 3 is a slightly longer and more difficult Meditation, so let me provide a little bit of background and then focus your attention on just a few reading questions.

At the center of Mediation 3 is a desire to avoid the problem presented by the possibility of an evil, deceiving God. 

This possibility was the great obstacle standing in the way of our indubitable knowledge that we exist to confidence to equal confidence that the physical world that we perceive is real. 

But given this problem, the escape is somewhat clear. If Descartes can prove that there exists a God and that this God is good (and has no evil), then this possibility of deception can be removed. 

But notice some limitations. Descartes cannot prove God exists by pointing to the physical world (which he knows only through he senses) and assert that there must be a good God that created this world. 

He cannot do this because the very existence of this physical world is in doubt. 

The only thing that is certain is that he exists as a thinking thing. And this his starting point.

Paragraphs 1-16 are important background, but the heart of the proof begins in paragraph 17 and follows to the end.

<QuestionBlock type="reading-content">
  <Question level={1}>As you read, can you develop a general sense of his proof for God's existence. How does he use his "thought" of God or the "idea of God" that he indubitably possess to conclude that a Good God must exist.</Question>
  <Question level={2}>What is unique about the idea of God in Descartes' mind (see for example para 22)</Question>
  <Question level={2}>How does this uniqueness lead to the conclusion that a good God must exist? (see for example paragraphs 32, 37, and 38)</Question>
  <Question level={1} type="reading-discussion">Are you convinced by this proof for God's existence? Why or why not?</Question>
</QuestionBlock>

Paragraph 48 serves as kind of introduction. He notes here that the "chief obstacle" to progress in science is the "obscurity of ideas and the ambiguity of terms"

<QuestionBlock type="reading-discussion">
  <Question level={1}>Can we reflect on this on a moment? Can we think of examples where the "ambiguity of terms" prevents scientific or intellectual progress? (This is good review work for our upcoming exam)</Question>
  <Question level={2}>Consider our work in epistemology thus far in the semester. How has the idea/meaning of "learning" been ambiguous and created puzzles and obstacles to progress?</Question>
  <Question level={2}>In which way has the word "to know" been full of ambiguity? (Consider the different between when I say "my Dog knows something" and when I say "I know something")</Question>
  <Question level={2}>How did Plato and Aristotle both try to make progress by being more precise about words like "learning" and "knowing"</Question>
</QuestionBlock>

Turning now to Paragraph 49.

<QuestionBlock type="reading-content">
  <Question level={1}>What idea or term does David Hume think is the most ambiguous and uncertain?</Question>
</QuestionBlock>

<QuestionBlock type="reading-content">
  <Question level={1}>According Hume (para 49) what is the origin of all our ideas?
    <Answer>
      "Impressions" are information we get from our internal and external senses. 
      The critical part of Hume's position is that, as he says, "all our ideas are copies of our impressions", thus "it is impossible for us to think anything" of which we do not have a prior sense impression?
    </Answer>
  </Question>
  <Question level={1}>How does this compare to Descartes? Does Descartes think it is possible for the mind to have an idea that is not derived from our sense experience?</Question>
  <Question level={1}>How does this compare to Plato? or Aristotle? Does Hume sound more like Plato or more Like Aristotle</Question>
  <Question level={2}>Why?</Question>
</QuestionBlock>
<QuestionBlock type="reading-content">
  <Question level={1}>How does identifying the origin ideas suggest a path for clarifying ideas and making them precise?
    <Answer>
      Hint: Consider the sentence in para 49 that begins with "But when we have pushed up definitions..." and follow it to the end of the paragraph.
    </Answer>
  </Question>
</QuestionBlock>

In paragraph 50, Hume begins to follow the method outlined in Para 49 in order to reach more clarity about the idea of a "necessary connection" or a "cause".

<QuestionBlock type="reading-content">
  <Question level={1}>According to Hume, when we trace the idea of a "necessary connection" back to its original impressions, what do we find?</Question>
  <Question level={2}>Does he think we find an impression of a "necessary connection"? In other words, does he think we see or hear such a connection?</Question>
  <Question level={2}>What is the purpose of his billiard-ball example? What point is he trying to make with this example?</Question> 
  <Question level={2}>If we never actually have a sense impression of a "cause", what kind of impression do we have that leads to our idea of a cause?</Question>
  <Question level={3}>Reflect a little bit? Do you think he is correct? Why or why not? Can you identify and experience where you felt like you "sensed" a "cause" or "necessary" connection?</Question>
</QuestionBlock>

In paragraphs 51 and 52, Hume turns to our "internal impressions" and looks to see if we every have an experiential impression of a "necessary connection"

<QuestionBlock type="reading-content">
  <Question level={1}>Why does he think the will's ability to move the body is mysterious?</Question>
  <Question level={1}>Why does this suggest that even here, we do not have a real impression of necessary connection or cause?</Question>
  <Question level={2}>How does the example of the man in sudden paralysis (middle of para 52) illustrate this point?</Question>
</QuestionBlock>

Hume begins at transition at paragraph 58 (Part II)

<QuestionBlock type="reading-content">
  <Question level={1}>Describe the transition we see at the beginning of paragraph 58</Question>
  <Question level={2}>What does Hume think he has shown in Part 1?</Question>
  <Question level={2}>What new task does he intend to accomplish in Part 2?</Question>
</QuestionBlock>

<QuestionBlock type="reading-content">
<Question level={1}>How do fragments 1 and 2 paint different portraits of the first philosopher?</Question>
<Question level={2}>What seems to be Thales’ primary field of study?</Question>
<Question level={2}>Why does Thales appear foolish and impractical in the first fragment?</Question>
<Question level={2}>According to the second fragment, why isn't Thales a rich businessman?</Question>
</QuestionBlock>

<QuestionBlock type="reading-content">
<Question level={1}>According to fragment 5, why do the early philosophers (including Thales) think that matter is the underlying principle of the world?</Question>
<Question level={2} type="reading-discussion">When the fragment discusses "principles," what do you think it means?</Question>
<Question level={2}>What kind of specific matter does Thales take to be the underlying principle of the world? Why?</Question>
</QuestionBlock>
<QuestionBlock type="reading-content">
<Question level={1}>According to fragment 9-10, what does Anaximander think is the first principle of the world? </Question>
<Question level={2} type="reading-discussion">How is this different from Thales?</Question>
</QuestionBlock>
<QuestionBlock type="reading-content">
<Question level={1}>How does Anaximenes disagree with both Thales and Anaximander about the nature of the single originative stuff? (See fragment 21.)</Question>
</QuestionBlock>

## A Question for Thales

Thales wanted to find a single cause or explanation for the universe. 
In pursuit of such an explanation he proposed that the entire universe 
is fundamentally made up of one element: water

But if everything is water, how is Thales to account for our "lived experience" of variety and difference. Maybe everything is water. But why doesn't it all look like water?
 
If you think about it, this is still a question today that needs explaining. 

I can point to an ice cube and you can tell me it is water. 
But then I can point to a glass of water and you will tell me it is also water. 
Again, I can point to a cloud in the sky and again you will tell me it is also water. 

<QuestionBlock type="reading-discussion">
<Question>How can three different things, with such diverse properties, appearances, and behaviors really be the "same" thing?</Question>
</QuestionBlock>

<span id="anaximenes-demo"/>

## Anaximenes on Condensation and Rarefaction 

Anaximenes took the above question seriously. 

If we're going to be able to explain the world in terms of a single cause (where this cause is some singular "stuff"), then the burden is on us to explain how this stuff can appear so "qualitatively different".

In the scene below, there are three qualitatively different objects (perhaps one is "hard" and one is "somewhat firm" and the third is "very soft"). Let us imagine that each is composed of "air" (imagined as cubes), which Anaximenes proposed as an alternative to water. 

Explore the three objects below. (Zoom in and out, rotate around and inspect each object.) The consider the questions below.

<BabylonViewerWrapper/>


<QuestionBlock type="reading-discussion">
<Question>Since each object is made of air (cubes), and in this case the same amount of cubes, what is left to explain our different experience of these three objects?</Question>
</QuestionBlock>

<QuestionBlock type="reading-content">
<Question level={1}>How does Anaximenes use the concept of condensation and rarefaction to explain our different experience of these objects?</Question>
</QuestionBlock>

<QuestionBlock type="reading-discussion">
<Question level={1}>Compare fragments 12 and 21. How can Anaximenes be seen as trying to add more precision to the account of change and variation already given by Anaximander?</Question>
</QuestionBlock>

<QuestionBlock type="reading-content">
<Question level={1}>According to fragment 24, why does "Air" always need to be moving?</Question>
</QuestionBlock>

<QuestionBlock type="reading-content">
<Question level={1}>In fragments, 26 and 28, how is "Air" used to explain the creation of the earth and the planets and the stars?</Question>
</QuestionBlock>

<QuestionBlock type="reading-discussion">
<Question level={1}>In terms of explaining the world as we know it, with all its variety, why might Anaximander's focus on the principle of the world as "moving" and "directive of other things" be seen as an advance over Thales's explanation of the world in terms of water alone? </Question>
<Question level={2}>What does it begin to account for that Thales's theory did not seem to address?  (Consider especially the introduction to this section and fragments 9, 11, and 12.)</Question>
</QuestionBlock>

<QuestionBlock>
<Question level={1} type="reading-content">
What do you think Heraclitus means by "logos" (Consider especially fragments 1,
2, 10, 11, 27)?
</Question>
</QuestionBlock>

<QuestionBlock>
<Question level={1} type="reading-content">How are the images of "appearance" versus "reality, "waking" versus "dreaming" used in these fragments?</Question>
<Question level={2}>Which fragments discuss these ideas?</Question>
<Question level={2} type="reading-discussion">Why do you think Heraclitus seems preoccupied with the difference between "appearance" and "reality"?</Question>
</QuestionBlock>

<QuestionBlock type="reading-content">
<Question level={1}>Why is Heraclitus fascinated with the image of fire? (See esp. fragment 49.)</Question>
<Question level={2} type="reading-discussion">Is it similar or different to the theories of Thales, Anaximander, or Anaximenes? How so?</Question>
<Question level={2}>Why does he associate it with the underlying "matter" of the world?</Question>
<Question level={2}>How is fire related to the frequently discussed ideas of change and rest? (See fragment 39, 40, 41, 55, 79, 81, 82.)</Question>
</QuestionBlock>

<QuestionBlock type="reading-content">
<Question level={1}>What is Heraclitus's general attitude toward other people in these fragments?</Question>
<Question level={2} type="reading-discussion">Which fragments appear to you as suggestive of this attitude?</Question>
</QuestionBlock>

<QuestionBlock type="reading-discussion">
<Question level={1}>In what way does Heraclitus's account of the world as one of constant change appear to you correct or incorrect, in agreement with your own experience or opposed to your own experience? </Question>
<Question level={2}>Explain where and how you have had these experiences and why they confirm or contradict Heraclitus's own view of the world as constantly in flux.</Question>
</QuestionBlock>

# Reading Questions Work through these reading questions with the reading first; then consider the class notes that follow. ## Parmenides Please make sure to read the editorial introduction to the fragments from Parmenides. According to this introduction, what are the three parts of Parmenides' poem? What is the central message of the section of his poem titled "Truth" (see fragments 2-8)? What conclusion does Parmenides reach about the possibility of change (see esp. 8.12-22)? What kinds of reasons does he offer for this claim? How might it connect to the two different "routes" introduced in fragment 6 or the division between "that which is" and "that which is not"? What is the central message of the third section titled Doxa, which begins at 8.50? Why are the opinions of mortals "deceitful"? Consider especially the "opinion" (or doxa) in fragment 19. How does this "opinion" compare to the truth asserted in the earlier section? ## Parmenides vs. Anaximenes Another way to think about Parmenides' contribution is to come back to Anaximenes's original position. Parmenides looked at Anaximenes's account of the world and asked some troubling questions. Anaximenes's used the different degrees of "density" (i.e. the space between air particles) to explain qualitative difference. [But recall our earlier 3D model illustrating Anaximenes's position](class-15#anaximenes-demo). Then ask, what is the "stuff" between the "cubes"? In other words, what is the space between the air particles? In this example, explore the "sphere" below. Try especially to go "inside" the sphere? (a "mouse scroll" should allow you to move inside and back out of the sphere). What do you see there? After exploring the "sphere", consider the following questions: What is the sphere? And consequently, what is the stuff between the cubes in which those cubes are suspended or floating? Is it NOTHING? If so, since each object has the same amount of cubes and "nothing" between them, shouldn't they all be qualitatively the same? Is it SOMETHING? If it is something, what, according Anaximenes must it be? And if the space between the cubes is just more of this "something", why would this threaten Anaximenes's explanation of qualitative difference? ## Zeno According to the editorial introduction to the section on Zeno, what is Zeno's relation to Parmenides? How is Zeno trying to show the consequences of Parmenides's position? Consider how this is argued for in fragment 1 (p. 66-67). Consider fragment 5 (p. 68) closely. How does this fragment attempt to prove that if there are many things, then, paradoxically, these many things must be both finite and infinite at the same time? Consider fragment 6 and 7. How do these arguments attempt to prove that our ideas of motion are impossible and contradictory? Consider fragment 12. How does Zeno argue for the absurdity of thinking about "place" as something that exists? What is your reaction to Zeno’s argument against motion in fragments 6 and 7? Do the arguments seem convincing? In what way? Since Zeno, like us, clearly has the experience of motion in his daily life, what do you think the ultimate goal of his arguments is? What might he be trying say about our sense-experience of the world? # Class Notes on Parmenides ## From Nothingness to a World without Change Parmenides's central positions comes from taking the idea of "nothingness" very seriously. As an example, stop for a moment and try to think of "nothing". Can you do it? What do you think of when try to think of "nothing"? Describe what you "see" when you do thisn Parmenides claims it can't be done. If you're thinking of "anything", then you are still thinking of "something". Thus, if you claim to be successfully thinking of "nothing", then you are actually still thinking of "something". For Parmenides, "nothing" is completely unintelligible. This might seem like a small claim, but Parmenides draws out some big implications from the unintelligibility of nothingness. The most important implication is what it means for one of our most common experiences, namely our experience of change. In direct opposition to Heraclitus, Parmenides asserts that change is actually not happening and cannot happen. Despite what your senses tell you, nothing changes. Why is Parmenides so confident? He gives us a version of the following argument. 1) First, if something comes to be from "already being", then it already is, and therefore it did not actually come to be. Consider P. 60, fragment 8, line 18-20) 2) Second, if something comes to be from "non-being", then it comes from nothing. (But nothing, if it is really nothing, can become something because it would first have to be something. Parmenides's view is often captured in the phrase "nothing comes from nothing".) Consider what he says on p. 59, fragment 8, line 6: > "For what birth will you seek out for it? How and from what did it grow? For what is not I will allow you neither to say nor to think…" We could formalize this argument even more: 1) If E (Exists), then A (Already exists) (p. 60, fragment 8, line 18-20) 2) If ~E (Not Exists), then N (nothing, because nothing comes from nothing) (p. 59, frag. 8, line 5-17) 3) Things either E (exists) or ~E (do not exists) C) Therefore, Everything A (Already exists) or N (is Nothing). Does this argument remind you of anything we've seen before? Why do you think the arguments are so similar? The result is that there is only one thing in the universe; it is the "What is" and it never changes in any way. ## Other Descriptions of the "What is" Let's consider more closely what this "What is" or "Being" is that Parmenides says never goes in or out of existence. Here you might consider closely Fragment 8, line 23 and following. I'll focus on four key characteristics below. ### 1. It is necessarily one, unified, and indivisible Why can't the "What is" be divided? Fredrick Copelston explains as follows: > "Because if it is not one but divided, then it must be divided by something other than itself. But Being cannot be divided by something other than itself, for besides being there is nothing." Consider the following example. Imagine I have a line.

And then I want to cut this line into distinct parts, so I break it up, like so: -|-|-|-|-|-|-|-|-|-|-|-|-|-|-|-|-|-|-|-|-|-|-|-|-|-|-|-|-|-|-|-|-|-|-|-|-|-|-|-|-|-|-|-|-|-|-|-|-|-|-|-|-|-|-|-|-|-|-|-|- If the horizontal line represents the "what is", and the "what is" is the only thing in the world that exists, what are the vertical lines in the above illustration? According to Parmenides, they can only be more of the "what is". Thus, the division is only an illusion. It is actually impossible to break up the line or divide it because whatever you try to use to separate or divide the line will just be more of the line itself. ### 2. It is complete - nothing can be added to it. Why might it seem like a problem if something could be "added" to the "What is"? Consider Fragment 8.24: > "And not all more in any way, which would keep it from holding together or at all less, but it is full of what-is…" Again Copelston states "…anything that was added to 'being', would itself be MORE being" (and thus would already be a part of being). ### 3. It is immovable, unchanging, and continuous Consider Fragment 8:25: > "But unchanging in the limits of great bonds it is without starting or ceasing…" Why can't the "What is" move? You might consider, to where would it move. If it tries to move to another place, what will already be there before it gets there? Won't the "What is" simply find that it was always already there. ### 4. It is necessary and eternal. The "What is" can never have a first moment in which it begins to be. Nor can it every cease to be. Consider Fragment 8.30: > "Remaining the same and in the same and by itself it lies and so remains there fixed; for mighty necessity holds it in bonds of a limit which holds it on all sides." This inference seems pretty straightforward. If the material stuff of the world cannot go in or out of being, if there is anything at all, it must have always exist. It therefore must be eternal and necessary. ## Conclusion: Appearance Versus Reality. If Parmenides is correct and the world really is an indivisible, unmoving and unchanging, single thing, what does this say about our experience of the world? If reason proves that changes is impossible, and yet our senses still perceive change, what are we supposed to conclude about experience of change? Parmenides thinks we must conclude that "all change is an illusion" and further "our experience of change is a deception". This corollary is perhaps Parmenides's greatest and most troubling contribution to the history of philosophy. By pointing out that reason tells us change cannot happen, despite the fact that our senses tell us that change does happen, he has created a dramatic division between "Reason" and "Sense", "Reality" and "Appearance". For him, reason proves (prior to any experience and sensation) that our senses deceive us and don't provide us with reliable access to the "real". He insists that reality is really very different than it appears. Thus, if I want to get access to the "real", I need to shut out my senses, and uses my reason alone to access what is truly true. Have we seen any other thinkers that share this view? Who?

As always, please be sure to read the biographical introduction to each of our thinkers.

<QuestionBlock type="reading-content">
<Question level={1}>Consider Aristotle's definition of wisdom in Book I, c. 1 closely.</Question>
<Question level={2}>Why does he not think that wisdom can be acquired through the senses?</Question>
<Question level={2}>Why is the master craftsman wiser than the manual craftsman?</Question>
</QuestionBlock>
<QuestionBlock type="reading-content">
<Question level={1}>According to Book I, c. 2, what kinds of causes does the wise person seek?</Question>
</QuestionBlock>

<Question level={2}>Which causes did we focus on in our reading from the Physics? Which have we not yet looked at closely?</Question>
</QuestionBlock>

<Question level={1}>According to Aristotle, which types of causes did the early philosophers focus on?</Question>
<Question level={2}>Why does this narrow focus lead directly to the conclusion that nothing changes? (See 983b10)</Question>
</QuestionBlock>
<QuestionBlock type="reading-content">
<Question level={1}>According to Aristotle, what eventually pushes these philosophers to look beyond the purely material cause (984a17-27)?</Question>
<Question level={2}>In what way, did they discover the "efficient cause"?</Question>
</QuestionBlock>
<QuestionBlock type="reading-content">
<Question level={1}>What is Aristotle's view toward Plato?</Question>
<Question level={2}>Why does the combination of "Heraclitean beliefs" and concern for eternal definitions lead Plato to posit a separate world of Forms?</Question>
<Question level={2}>Why is Aristotle critical of the notion that Forms exist in a separate world? (See both chapter 6 and 9.)</Question>
</QuestionBlock>
<QuestionBlock type="reading-discussion">
<Question level={1}>Why, according to Aristotle, was the efficient cause eventually seen as insufficient? In what way do you see this insufficiency leading to something similar to Socrates' concern for the best arrangement and the discovery of the Forms or formal causality (see esp. 984b10)?</Question>
</QuestionBlock>

### Questions for Aristotle *Metaphysics*, Book XII, pp. 332–344

<QuestionBlock type="reading-content">
<Question level={1}>What is the central puzzle introduced in Book XII, c. 6?</Question>
<Question level={2}>Why does Aristotle say that there "must be a principle of the sort whose essence is actuality" (1071b19)?</Question>
<Question level={2}>What problem would occur if everything in the world only had the potentiality for motion or change, but there was no actuality that could come along and initiate that change?</Question>
<Question level={2}>How is Plato said to address this issue?</Question>
</QuestionBlock>
<QuestionBlock type="reading-content">
<Question level={1}>In the first paragraph of chapter 7, what are the two kinds of movers that Aristotle introduces to solve the problem introduced in chapter 6?</Question>
<Question level={2}>How are these movers similar?</Question>
<Question level={2}>How are these movers different?</Question>
</QuestionBlock>
<QuestionBlock type="reading-content">
<Question level={1}>Consider how this analysis of eternal motion in terms of an unmoved mover and everlasting circular movement is mapped on to Aristotle's vision of the stars and the planets in chapter 8.</Question>
</QuestionBlock>
<QuestionBlock type="reading-content">
<Question level={1}>Finally, in chapter 9, how does Aristotle describe the divine life of the unmoved mover?</Question>
<Question level={2}>Why does he argue that, if the unmoved mover is the best substance, it will be engaged in an ever-lasting contemplation of itself (1074b34)?</Question>
</QuestionBlock>
<QuestionBlock type="reading-discussion">
<Question level={1}>According to the second paragraph of chapter 7, how does the substance that "initiates motion without being moved" initiate motion?</Question>
<Question level={2}>In what way is this comparable to an object of love initiating movement in the lover? How so?</Question>
<Question level={2}>Can you think of an example of this kind of initiation of movement?</Question>
</QuestionBlock>

### Questions for Copleston and Russell, 'A Debate on the Argument from Contingency', pp. 5-11

First a note: Before getting bogged down in the details of this debate, try to step back and appreciate the whole. Whether or not you can follow every argument or claim that is made, observe in general how important the notion of "cause" or "explanation" is in this debate. Here we can we see how critical these metaphysical concepts are to foundational questions like, 'Does God exists?'. A key goal here is just to see how debates in metaphysics are in conducted in the modern area and to appreciate how the questions that occupied the ancient philosophers continue to be relevant today.


<QuestionBlock type="reading-content">
  <Question level={1}>What definition of God does Copleston begin with?</Question>
  <Question level={2} type="reading-discussion">Is this similar to or different from the "unmmoved mover" that Aristotle discovers in book 12 of the Metaphysics?</Question>
</QuestionBlock>

<QuestionBlock type="reading-content">
  <Question level={1}>What is Copleston's definition of a "contingent being"? (p. 6b)</Question>
  <Question level={1}>What is a "necessary being"?</Question>
  <Question level={1}>Why does Copleston think a universe of "contingent beings" demands a "necessary being"?</Question>
</QuestionBlock>

After considerable back and forth on pages 6-8, at the very bottom of page 8b, Russell points out that the real crux of the matter is that Copleston believes everything must have a "sufficient reason" (p. 8b, bottom).

<QuestionBlock type="reading-content">
  <Question level={1}>Can you get a sense of why Copleston believes there must be a "sufficient reason" for everything? </Question>
  <Question level={2}>What happens to our understanding of the universe if there is a sufficient reason for everything? (See page 9b.)</Question>
  <Question level={1}>Why doesn't this bother Russell?</Question>
  <Question level={2}>While admitting that many particular things have causes, why doesn't he think there must be a cause of the totality?</Question>
  <Question level={3}>What is the argument (by analogy) about "every person who exists having a mother..." (p. 10a) and how does this support his point?</Question>
  <Question level={3}>Why does he think contemporary physicists might support his point (i.e. that while there might be particular chains of cause and effect, there need not be an explanation for everything or for the totality?) (see pp. 10b, 11a, and 11b).</Question>
</QuestionBlock>

<Question level={1}>Book X.6-8 closes the Ethics in the way Book I opened, with a discussion of the good life.</Question>

<QuestionBlock type="reading-content">
<Question level={1}>Just for the sake of review, note that in chapter 6, he states "happiness is not a state/disposition".</Question>

</QuestionBlock>

<QuestionBlock type="reading-content">
<Question level={1}>What's the difference between a virtuous activity and a "pleasant amusement" (c. 6)?</Question>
</QuestionBlock>

<QuestionBlock type="reading-content">
<Question level={1}>What does Aristotle recognize as the "highest activity" (c. 7)?</Question>
<Question level={2}>Are there any reasons given to support this conclusion? (There are at least six.)</Question>
</QuestionBlock>

<QuestionBlock type="reading-content">
<Question level={1}>How does this life differ from the life lived according to "practical virtues" (c. 7, near 1177a22)?</Question>
</QuestionBlock>

<Question level={1}>Why does he say that the contemplative life is "too high for man"?</Question>
